title: House Democrats: No need to increase gas tax for road funding
text:
Buy Photo House Minority Leader Scott Pelath, D-Michigan City, supported the Supreme Court decision on Obamacare subsidies, saying "the big winners here are those millions of workers who will be able care for themselves and their families." (Photo: Charlie Nye / The Star 2013 file photo) Buy Photo
Indiana House Democrats on Monday proposed an alternative way to raise money for road funding that wouldn't rely on a gas tax increase, though it would freeze other pending tax cuts.
Their proposal would raise about $900 million each year by freezing future corporate income tax cuts, cutting "waste, fraud and abuse" and dedicating all sales tax on gasoline and special fuels directly to roads immediately.
It also would rely on reducing the almost $2 billion surplus that Republicans have touted to around $1.3 billion, while reducing waste by $300 million per year, Democratic Leader Scott Pelath said Monday.
“It’s not necessary to have new taxes or tolls in order to reinvest," Pelath said. "The problem we have up until this point is not a problem of revenue. It’s been a problem of priorities."
Republicans, who have overwhelming control of the House, have proposed a road-funding plan that would increase the gas tax by 10 cents a gallon, phase in the use of all gas tax money entirely for roads and require a study on interstate tolls.
During earlier testimony on the House Republican plan, Democrats first brought up decreasing the corporate tax cuts as a way to save money for roads. Since 2011, the corporate tax rate has decreased 2.5 percentage points, and will continue to decrease until the 2021 fiscal year.
By freezing future cuts on corporate tax, Democrats hope to save $100 million per year by the 2021 fiscal year.
House Democrats initially proposed eliminating the final year of an income tax break for those earning $150,000 or more per year and couples earning $300,000. But they dropped that portion of the plan later Monday, reducing estimates of the first year of their road funding plan to $782 million.
House Speaker Brian Bosma, R-Indianapolis, said the Democrat proposal would hurt the state's business climate.
"Their plan would raise taxes, result in cuts to education and jeopardize our state’s AAA credit rating," Bosma said in a statement. "In the last month alone, we have heard of many jobs and business investments coming to Indiana in direct response to our state’s top-ranked business climate and pro-growth policies. Raising taxes on Hoosier employers is the wrong move and would be a major employment setback for the average worker."
